content.question: Which of the following best describes the efficiency of dry scrubbers at removing particles that are less than 2 micrometers in diameter?

choices.label: Dry scrubbers are less than 20% efficient at removing particles less than <math alttext="1 micrometer" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and increase to over 50% efficiency at removing particles between 1 and <math alttext="2 micrometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Dry scrubbers are between 50% and 90% efficient at removing particles less than <math alttext="2 micrometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, depending on the flow rate.

Dry scrubbers are between 5% and 40% efficient at removing particles less than <math alttext="2 micrometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in size.

Dry scrubbers are less than 10% efficient at removing particles less than <math alttext="1 micrometer" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in size.

content.answer: Dry scrubbers are less than 10% efficient at removing particles less than <math alttext="1 micrometer" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in size.
